articles.headline: As Democrats Nudge Bernie Sanders, G.O.P. Tries to Rein In Donald Trump
articles.snippet: President Obama is expected to meet with Mr. Sanders as part of an effort to ease him out of the race, while Republicans were seeking a more subdued version of Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: President Obama is expected to meet with Mr. Sanders as part of an effort to ease him out of the race, while Republicans were seeking a more subdued version of Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democratic and Republican leaders on Wednesday renewed their fitful efforts to impose greater order on a freewheeling presidential race and to bring to heel a pair of political renegades, Senator Bernie Sanders and Donald J. Trump, whose upstart campaigns have roiled the political establishment.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns, Michael D. Shear and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Lawyers Ordered to Testify on Client’s Tax Evasion Case
articles.snippet: Two lawyers representing Morris Zukerman, accused of avoiding $45 million in taxes, were compelled to appear before a grand jury investigating him.
articles.abstract: Two lawyers representing Morris Zukerman, accused of avoiding $45 million in taxes, were compelled to appear before a grand jury investigating him.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is not every day that two prominent lawyers are brought before a federal grand jury and directed to provide documents and testimony about conversations they had with a wealthy client.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Bangladesh Says It Now Knows Who’s Killing the Bloggers
articles.snippet: The police have implicated two militant groups in an accelerating series of attacks over the past three years and say they are preparing to round up their leaders.
articles.abstract: The police have implicated two militant groups in an accelerating series of attacks over the past three years and say they are preparing to round up their leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — The young man, inching past a crowded checkpoint near a truck stand in Bangladesh’s capital, caught the attention of an alert police officer.
articles.byline: By Geeta Anand and Julfikar Ali Manik

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton on Winning, and Why Her Mother Would Be Nervous
articles.snippet: A day after claiming the Democratic presidential nomination, the candidate paused for a moment to savor her success and consider the next phase.
articles.abstract: A day after claiming the Democratic presidential nomination, the candidate paused for a moment to savor her success and consider the next phase.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after claiming her party’s nomination for president, an exhilarated Hillary Clinton said she was “still processing” the emotions of the moment on Wednesday as she heard from people around the globe both excited about her success and deeply anxious about her Republican rival, Donald J. Trump.

articles.headline: Historic Import of Hillary Clinton’s Victory Is One More Source of Division
articles.snippet: For some, it was an inspiring moment. For others, there were chills and discomfort that this step forward in our national story was unfolding with this particular woman.
articles.abstract: For some, it was an inspiring moment. For others, there were chills and discomfort that this step forward in our national story was unfolding with this particular woman.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton swept onto the stage at her victory rally Tuesday night, the thunderbolt of history struck many Americans, no matter their love or loathing for her: A woman could be the next president of the United States.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: The Stock Market Is Optimistic, So What’s Your Excuse?
articles.snippet: Investors have felt plenty of anxiety about the elections, interest rates, China, Europe and jobs. But the market has rebounded to near-record heights.
articles.abstract: Investors have felt plenty of anxiety about the elections, interest rates, China, Europe and jobs. But the market has rebounded to near-record heights.
articles.lead_paragraph: Has the election made you anxious about the future of the United States? Do you feel as if your job is not secure in this lukewarm economy? Are you just generally in the dumps?

articles.headline: Drug That Killed Prince Is Making Mexican Cartels Richer, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: American officials warn that the cartels are using their own labs to produce fentanyl, a synthetic opioid tied to a rise in overdose deaths.
articles.abstract: American officials warn that the cartels are using their own labs to produce fentanyl, a synthetic opioid tied to a rise in overdose deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The drug that killed Prince has become a favorite of Mexican cartels because it is extremely potent, popular in the United States — and immensely profitable, American officials say.
